On 6/15/05, Gordon Mohr (@Internet Archive) <gojomo@...> wrote:
> M=
att Ittigson wrote:
> > Some change in the code between earlier today and M=
ay 31st has caused
> > a massive slowdown in the speed which I'm downloadin=
g data.  On the
> > same machine, configured in the same way, a version of =
Heritrix I
> > built from CVS, from earlier today, could not muster more th=
an 30K/s
> > on the same seed file that the May 31st version is currently d=
oing
> > 728K/s.
> >
> > Perhaps the difference is in configuration?  Maybe=
 I'm enabling a
> > newer configuration variable which is slowing things do=
wn?  The
> > difference between the order.xml files are only additions in t=
he newer
> > version:
> >
> > reread-seeds-on-config: true
> > use-bdb-for-=
cookies: true
> > the universal extractor (with default configuration)
> > =
LinkScoper instead of Postselector (with default configuration)
> >
> > Wou=
ld any of the log files be of use to track down the problem?
> 
> Depending=
 on when you grabbed the code, there was a synchronization
> bug that could=
 corrupt a statistics HashMap, one possible symptom
> of which was threads =
spinning in HashMap put() -- and thus also
> soaking up cycles, slowing oth=
er threads.
> 
> Most useful for diagnosing this problem, and some others l=
ike it,
> is the web UI threads report or a SIGQUIT JVM threads dump, plus
=
> watching an OS tool like 'top'.

I'll look into whether the newest stuff =
fixed the problem.

> This particular problem is fixed... but keep in mind =
that CVS HEAD
> is often 'bleeding edge'. Using it, you'll be subject to br=
and new
> bugs -- up to and including things that render the crawler
> inop=
erative until fixed.

I got tired of being out-of-date tracking the automat=
ed builds since
there was no diff mechanism that didn't involve getting a c=
ompletely
new tree (and remaking the small code and integration changes to =
each
tree).  CVS at least allowed a way to get at the newer versions in
eas=
ier to digest chunks.

Since I do want to keep up with the bleeding edge ch=
anges, probably
I'll keep my own versions of the distribution files around =
from known
good builds as a way to protect against those kinds of issues.

=
> If you use CVS HEAD, it can also be good to keep an eye on the
> 'archive=
-crawler-cvs' CVS commits mailing list -- so you see some
> indication of b=
ig changes and latest fixes:
> 
>    http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/for=
um.php?forum_id=3D34924

I have been, thanks.  Its actually what prompted t=
he last update, as
there was some feature that looked interesting (can't re=
member exactly
what).  I also want to get at the new JMX stuff that just go=
t checked
in.

I hope this was an appropriate place for a message about pro=
blems I
was having tracking that code.  In the future should those go here?=
 
To the developers checking changes in since the last good build?

Thanks =
for your help.

-matt
